awd_titl_txt: CC*IIE Integration: Collaborative Research: EPSON: Embracing Parallel Networks and Storage for Predictable End-to-End Data Movement
awd_abstract_narration:
Geographically distributed scientific communities require increasingly sophisticated data transfer mechanisms that can handle the challenges of sharing large datasets over heterogeneous networks. These challenges include optimization of networks with different configurations and protocols, I/O mechanisms to efficiently read and write to parallel storage, and the varying demands of widely different data transfer workloads.

To address these challenges, the EPSON project is developing, implementing, and evaluating application programming interfaces and tools that facilitate end-to-end parallel data transfers. EPSON researchers focus on three areas: (1) enabling parallel network data movement, by taking into account the diversity of parallel network characteristics of both shared networks and infrastructures with dedicated circuits and paths and effectively balancing the flows among paths for more predictable performance; (2) developing a GridFTP data storage interface, enabling scalable I/O to and from parallel filesystems -- critical for campus infrastructures to deal with large-scale datasets; and (3) devising mechanisms that overlap network transfers with storage I/O and incorporate data-staging heuristics, matching the impedance between storage and networking capabilities to improve end-to-end data transfers. The project involves close collaboration with application scientists, with the objective of providing advanced networking tools to support the requirements of the applications deployed at the University of Chicago and Northern Illinois University campuses.

por.por_cntn:
The EPSON (Embracing Parallel Networks and Storage for Predictable End-to-End Data Movement) project focused on addressing large-scale data transfer challenges. The tools developed as part of this work were made available to application scientists for use at the Advanced Photon Source (APS), a DOE User Facility located at Argonne National Laboratory. The APS provides ultra-bright, high-energy storage ring-generated x-ray beams for research in almost all scientific disciplines and is a used by thousands of scientists each year. The massive datasets generated by APS experiments are typically moved back to home laboratories or institutions for post-processing and analysis. EPSON tools have enabled 10 percent to 78 percent performance gains over other state-of-the-art data movement tools, depending on the characteristics of the datasets, end systems, and the network link. Our goal throughout this project was to evolve existing prototypes into more robust software elements. Through software integration and enhancement, we provided broadly useful capabilities to the collaborating science projects and to the broader NSF research community. Some of the EPSON enhancements have already been integrated into GridFTP. The EPSON team included experts in transport protocols, parallel data movement tools, and application code development for cosmology at the University of Chicago (UC); and experts in parallel file systems, network services, and parallel analysis tools at Northern Illinois University (NIU). The team identified a number of data movement needs and gaps in applications. The project has had a major impact with large-scale data transfers that coupled the data output and analysis to computational resources. The team engaged researchers from several science domains to develop and deliver useful tools. The team is now working with these users to promote the effort within their respective communities. The PIs recruited computer science graduate students to participate in the evaluation of the EPSON tools, exposing them to high-speed networks and advanced networking tools, while providing them an opportunity to participate in an interdisciplinary collaboration and software development effort as additional career preparation.
Major activities of EPSON project are highlighted below:

  • Gather requirements from Hardware/Hybrid Accelerated Cosmology Code and x-ray Photon Correlation Spectroscopy teams
  • Develop EPSON parallel m-to-n data movement 
  • Test parallel m-to-n network data transfers
  • Evaluate m-to-n transfers on Energy Sciences Network (ESnet) 100G testbed
  • Add parallel filesystem optimizations in EPSON and evaluate
  • Add LOSF (Lots of Small Files) and parallel checksum capabilities
  • Evaluate LOSF optimization using UC & NIU campus infrastructure
  • Develop mechanisms for network and storage impedance matching
  • Evaluate impedance matching on ESnet 100G testbed UC and NIU environment
  • Evaluate EPSON for near real-time APS to NIU data movement
